thread.title: Parkland girls volleyball provides Liberty with unforgiving measuring stick in EPC final
thread.title_full: Parkland girls volleyball provides Liberty with unforgiving measuring stick in EPC final

title: Parkland girls volleyball provides Liberty with unforgiving measuring stick in EPC final
text:
By Kyle Craig | For lehighvalleylive.com on October 23, 2015 1:38 AM, updated October 23, 2015 2:19 AM View/Post Comments 
In the weeks since Parkland High School’s girls volleyball team swept Liberty on Sept. 10, the Hurricanes have distinguished themselves from the rest of the Eastern Pennsylvania Conference. 
Seventeen consecutive victories have Liberty at 19-1, the No. 2 team in the area according to lehighvalleylive’s rankings. 
Those 17 wins, more specifically the last two in the EPC playoffs, have given the Hurricanes another opportunity to test the nationally ranked Trojans. 
Liberty, which defeated Nazareth in the semifinals, and Parkland (18-0), which downed Central Catholic, will meet 1 p.m. Saturday for the EPC championship. 
“They have good ball control,” Trojans coach Mike Krause said of Liberty. “They’ll keep the ball in play. They’ll be very scrappy. They’ll put it on you to either score or give them points. They have the ability to score from every position.” 
The Trojans, defending PIAA Class AAA champs, of course, have the ability to inflict punishment from anywhere as well. 
COMPLETE COVERAGE : Parkland, Liberty advance to EPC girls volleyball final 
Their five seniors are well known: Kristin Krause, Siena Salvaggio, Avery Perosa, Sam Webber and Erika Foose. Mike Krause has been pleased with the contributions from younger players Morgan Sherwin, Kirah Dreisbach, Megan Shaw and Grace Steurer, too. 
Liberty’s lineup is not nearly as senior-centric. Senior setter Maddie Capuano is distributing the ball, but beyond her the Hurricanes turn to juniors Amanda Rachwal, Sydney Wilson, Taylor Rezac and Kristin Kaleycik, sophomore Grace Mittl and freshman Lina Perugini. 
Hurricanes coach Missy Lynn feels her team has evolved since the third game of the campaign. 
“It shined a spotlight on our weaknesses, which we’ve been working on all season long,” she said. “I think that we’re a better team than we were at the beginning of the year.” 
Obstructing Parkland’s powerful swings will be a high priority. 
“Hopefully, we can slow their hits down,” Lynn said. “If we can slow their hits down, our defense can pick up the balls.” 
Foose was impressed with what she saw from Liberty. 
“I think they are a very, very good defensive team,” the senior said. “I see them flying on the court. It blows my mind, actually. I think it’s going to be a challenge for us to try to put the ball down. We’re going to have to step up our game a lot and it’s going to be an exciting match.” 
Upsetting the Trojans and earning a conference title would be a gigantic accomplishment for the 2015 ’Canes and the program as a whole. Mike Krause knows what’s at stake for the opposition. 
“I think Liberty is going to come in with something to prove to its own program,” he said. “They’ve grown so much under Missy. This is something where they can really measure themselves … They’re going to have a lot of energy, which is the way it should be.” 
The enthusiasm is a certainty, whether there’s been enough progress to test Parkland’s fortified position atop the EPC remains to be seen.
